data.title: What’s the difference between an MBE, OBE and CBE? Meaning of every rank of the 2023 New Year Honours list
data.meta_description: Honours have been bestowed by members of the Royal Family for centuries in the UK
data.text:
The annual honours list will soon be published by The Gazette, as it is every year.

The list aims to recognise the achievements and services of people from across the UK and from all walks of life with various forms of titles.

Honours have been bestowed by monarchs in some form since the Middle Ages, and are now announced twice a year – at new year and in June on the date of the late Queen’s official birthday.

Last year Chris Whitty, England’s chief medical officer (CMO), and his deputy Jonathan Van-Tam both received honours, as did Scotland’s CMO Dr Gregor Smith and Wales’ Frank Atherton.

What is the difference between the honours?

Honours lists typically comprise knights and dames, appointments to the Order of the British Empire and gallantry awards.

Here are the ranks in descending order:

Companions of Honour (CH)

The Order of the Companions of Honour was founded on 4 June, 1917 by George V and it limited to just 65 members at any one time. Appointments go to those who have made a long-standing contribution to arts, science, medicine or government.

Order of the Bath (DCB/KCB/CB)

This recognises the work of senior military officials and civil servants.

England’s CMO Chris Whitty (KCB) and chief scientific adviser, Sir Patrick Vallance (KCB), were honoured in last year’s New Year Honours list.

Order of St Michael and St George (Knight/GCMG/KCMG/DCMG/CMG)

This recognises service in a foreign country, or in relation to foreign and Commonwealth affairs, such as the work of diplomats overseas.

Last year, James Bond star Daniel Craig was made a Companion of the Order, which is equivalent to a CBE and means he can use the post-nominals CMG, following his final outing as 007 in No Time To Die.

Knighthood and damehood (Knight/DBE)

These are usually bestowed on people who have made a major contribution at national level, who can use the titles Dame and Sir.

England’s deputy CMO, Jonathan Van-Tam, Wales’ CMO Frank Atherton and Scotland’s CMO Dr Gregor Smith were made knights in 2022.

Commanders of the Order of the British Empire (CBE)

People are recognised under this honour if they have have a prominent but lesser role at national level, or a leading role at regional level.

It also goes to those who make a distinguished, innovative contribution to any area.

Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE)

People are made an Officer of the Order of the British Empire if they have a major local role in any activity, including people whose work has made them known nationally.

Among the 253 who were honoured in this way in 2022 were Olympians Adam Peaty and Tom Daley.

Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE)

This rank recognises outstanding achievements or service to the community which have had a long-term significant impact.

British Empire Medal (BEM)

The BEM was reintroduced in 2012 by then prime minister David Cameron as part of his attempt to make the honours system “classless”, saying too few people making a difference in their areas were made MBEs.

The medal went to 361 people in the 2022 New Year Honours.
